Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics of Excited Electronic States in DNA Strands
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this awwrd, the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanisms-A (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Bern Kohler of Montana State University to investigate the photophysics of double-stranded DNA. Double-stranded DNA appears to have enhanced stability against photo-degradation, and the Kohler group is undertaking a detailed investigation to better understand the mechanistic underpinnings of this photochemical stability. In additional experiments, Prof. Kohler and his research students will investigate how the photochemistry of DNA differs in so-called deep eutectic solvents (DES). Prof. Kohler's research has important implications in biology and medicine, in that understanding the way DNA interacts with light has direct bearing on understanding the ways that ultraviolet light from the sun can damage skin. Students working in the Kohler laboratory receive training at the interface of physical chemistry and biology, as preparation for careers in the acedemic or biotechnology sectors.The Kohler research group includes active participation of undergraduate students in authentic research. In addition, Prof. Kohler and his group members are engaged in outreach to K-12 students and teachers in the state of Montana, through a variety of established programs, such as Montana State University's Science Math Resource Center and the Montana Space Grant Consortium.

Professor Bern Kohler and his research group will conduct detailed photochemistry experiments using ultrafast laser methods to investigate the interesting photophysics of double-stranded DNA. Questions remain as to how exactly double-stranded DNA photochemically decays after electronic excitation. In the present award, Professor Kohler and his group will conduct a number of experiments to develop a better understanding of the photochemical details. Experiments to be conducted include: (1) a study of concerted proton-electron transfer (CPET) in AT and GC DNA using time-resolved infrared (TRIR) spectroscopy; (2) a collaborative study with Dr. Kimberly de La Harpe of the USAF Academy on the photochemistry of an oligonucleotide with TRIR spectroscopy that has been studied previously with UV/Visible transient absorbance (TA) spectroscopy; (3) a TRIR and TA study of miniduplexes synthesized for the Kohler group in a collaboration with Prof. Cynthia Burrows of the University of Utah; and (4) a new thrust investigating the photochemistry of DNA in DES's. Experimental work will benefit from insight provided by the theoretical group of Professor Roberto Improta of the National Research Council of Italy's Institute of Biostructures and Bioimaging.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the chemistry that is initiated by light (i.e., photochemistry) has been of great interest for many years. Light creates excited electronic states that generally persist for no more than a few billionths of a second. The study of ultraviolet (UV) excited states thus requires the extremely high time resolution provided by lasers that produce femtosecond pulses of light (one femtosecond is one millionth of one billionth of a second). UV radiation from the sun damages DNA, causing mutations that lead to skin cancer. This project leveraged advances in ultrafast laser technology as well as advances in using computers to predict spectra to study excited states in DNA.

Intellectual Merit. The DNA nucleobases (A, G, C, and T) are the UV-absorbing building blocks of DNA. Previous work has shown that these small organic molecules are highly resistant to UV damage due to the very short lifetimes of their excited electronic states. This project focused on understanding the deactivation pathways for excited states in DNA strands composed of two or more nucleobases. The nucleobases in a DNA strand are in contact, and this proximity gives rise to new ways for energy to relax. This project showed that UV radiation causes electrons to transfer between adjacent bases on the same DNA strand. This charge separation can cause a proton to hop between two bases within a base pair that joins two different DNA strands. These events are unique to the multi-nucleobase assemblies found in DNA strands and were not anticipated from previous experiments that examined only single nucleobases. Understanding photoinduced charge transfer reactions in DNA triggered by UV was a major aim of this project.

Experiments were performed on DNA strands by exciting them with femtosecond UV laser pulses and recording absorption spectra with femtosecond infrared laser pulses. Photogenerated radicals and radical ions were identified through their distinctive vibrational resonances. These experiments revealed that excited states in DNA dissipate their excess energy by distinct pathways. One pathway takes place in several picoseconds and involves the movement of a hydrogen atom between the two complementary strands of a DNA duplex. The second pathway, in which an electron hops from one base to another within the same strand, while a proton moves across the two strands, occurs ten times more slowly. The branching between these pathways depends sensitively on structure, isotopic composition, and solvent properties.

To investigate the role played by the solvent, experiments were performed on DNA strands dissolved in deep eutectic solvents (DES), members of a novel class of ionic liquids. These highly viscous solvents are able to solubilize DNA without significantly altering its structure. The viscous DES responds more slowly to the changes in charges induced by UV excitation, strongly affecting excited state relaxation. 

Further studies were conduced on DNA strands containing the modified nucleobase 2-aminopurine (2Ap), a powerful fluorescence probe used to study the structure and dynamics of nucleic acids. Computer simulations of 2Ap-labeled dinucleotides were carried out to study the stacking motions of pairs of bases that lead to fluorescence quenching. The analysis revealed that base stacking and fluorescence quenching occur on similar timescales. The results set the stage for using measured emission decay signals to probe folding and unfolding transitions in nucleic acids and for validating the computer force fields used to simulate the motions of DNA molecules.

 

Broader Impacts. The impact of the supported work extends beyond the field of photochemical damage to DNA. DNA features non-covalent interactions such as hydrogen bonding that are commonplace in nanoscale assemblies of smaller molecular units. Study of elementary events initiated by light in DNA strands thus aids the understanding of similar events in assemblies of organic absorbers. Knowledge of how excited electronic states change in time in DNA is valuable for understanding how to control energy or charge flow in new materials, while minimizing undesired photochemical pathways that result in damage.

A total of 8 individuals (2 postdocs, 4 graduate students, and 2 undergraduate students) received advanced training in how to conduct research using state-of-the-art spectroscopic and computational techniques and professionally communicate the results. Two Ph.D. dissertations were completed based on project findings. One graduate student completed a weeklong science communication master class and interacted with two research groups in Bristol, England. Prof. Kimberly de La Harpe from the U.S. Air Force Academy, a primarily undergraduate institution (PUI), completed a short-term research stay with the PI’s research group each summer during the project period and co-authored several publications. Lectures on research into DNA photodamage were given to public audiences in Ohio, Colorado, and Montana. Interactive activities on UV photochemistry were developed and shared with K-12 school children.
